Graphical abstract The limitation of isolated metal active sites in single atom catalysts (SAC) hinder their application in hydrogenation reactions, necessitating the creation of additional active site beyond the metal site. This study introduces pyridinic N and S atoms into the N/C sheet, optimally adjusting the local environment of the Co site. This adjustment synergistically enhances H2 activation, H diffusion, and promotes the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline. The sterically hindered Co acidic site and N basic site, known as frustrated Lewis pairs, in defect-containing Co-N3SN-def1 model cooperatively facilitate the highly efficient cleavage of the H2 molecule with a barrier of only 0.37 eV. The findings suggest that the pyridinic N site in the Co-N3SN-def1 model acts as a reservoir for *H, significantly contributing to the enhanced activity for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The mechanism unveiled in this study offers valuable insights for designing efficient heterogeneous catalysts for target hydrogenation reactions. Keywords Single atom catalyst Nitrobenzene hydrogenation Density functional theory frustrated Lewis pair H dissociation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have exhibited distinctive reactivity and selectivity towards various target reactions, owing to the highly dispersed metal atoms with uniform and specific coordination environment. Since the pioneering work of Zhang and co-workers in 2011, [1] which isolated Pt atoms on FeOx and demonstrated remarkably high activity and stability for the oxidation of CO, the development of SACs supported over diverse supports, including metal oxides, porous materials, and graphitic carbon, has been rapidly advancing. These advancements have significantly deepened our understanding of the molecular processes on catalyst surfaces. Many reported SACs consist of single metal atoms (M) coordinated to four nitrogen atoms within the graphitic sheet, forming an M−N4−C configuration (Fe-N4-C, Co-N4-C, Ni-N4-C, etc). Late transition metals, such as Fe, Co, and Ni, are commonly used as M due to their stability and activity for numerous reactions, as confirmed by both experimentally and theoretically. [2–4] Unlike traditional metal nanoparticles, whose reaction activity and selectivity are significantly influenced by the various exposed surface facets and interfacial structures, [5,6]the metal atom confined within the planar sheet of SAC is considered as the unique active site. Consequently, SACs are expected to exhibit higher activity and selectivity, making them highly promising materials for diverse heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Enhancing the activities of SACs for target reactions, such as the hydrogenation reactions, through unique electronic properties has been demonstrated to be feasible. [7–19] In recent years, numerous studies have shown that the designed SACs with tailored coordination environments can serve as efficient electrocatalysts for the reduction of CO2 into valuable products. [20–25] During these electrocatalytic processes, H is generated from the dissociation of H2O in the solution rather than at the active site on the surface of SAC. As a result, the adsorption of CO2 molecule at the metal site is less affected, making it relatively easier to modulate the electronic structures of the electrocatalysts with dispersed metal atoms, thereby achieving enhanced activity. In contrast, designing SACs in thermocatalysis with optimal electronic structure is more intricate, as multiple factors must be considered simultaneously, including the competing adsorption of H2 and reactant, H2 dissociation and diffusion, reaction barriers, and the product desorption. Recent efforts have been made to employ the SACs for enhancing hydrogenation reactions via thermocatalysis by modulating the electronic structure of metal sites and the local coordination environment. [26–34] Density functional theory (DFT) studies were conducted to screen 12 late transition metal single atom supported N-doped carbon based catalysts M1-N4/C SACs, [30] and potential rate-determining steps, including the H2 dissociation and the second N-O bond breaking, were obtained for various SACs with their different electronic structures. The Ru1-N4/C SAC was identified as the most promising catalyst for nitrobenzene hydrogenation due to its low barrier for H2 cleavage and moderate barrier of 0.99 eV for the second N-O bond breaking. By incorporating heteroatom S into N-coordinated cobalt single atom catalyst, Liu’s group [32] reported that the N, S dual-coordinated Co1S1N3 acts as an effective active site for the hydrogenation of nitro compounds, attributed to the enhanced desorption of H from the active site. Generally, it is believed that the metal site and the coordinated N site are the potential active sites for the adsorption of reactants (intermediates) and the cleavage of H2 molecules. Although significant progress has been made in recent years towards the design of transition metal atom-anchored C/N SACs for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, there are still some controversies regarding to the reaction mechanisms, and ample room for improving the hydrogenation activity via the modulation of the coordination environment around the single metal site. [33,35]. Frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) [36–38] have gained significant attention due to their remarkable ability to cleave H2 molecules, and have been introduced into non-noble metal based heterogeneous catalysts to enhance their performance in hydrogenation reactions. [39–44] Several research groups have reported that the SACs with inherent cavities act as FLP-containing catalysts. Very recently, Liu et al. reported the synthesis of stable Cu1/CN with a Cu-N4 configuration and two basic N sites in the same N6 cavity on the CN sheet, [31 ]achieving an unprecedented selectivity (100 %) and high activity (TOF = 2.9 × 103h−1) in the selective hydrogenation of 4-nitrostyrene. The Cu site and N sites were calculated to favor the adsorption of 4-nitrostyrene and H, respectively, with reasonable adsorption strength, thereby collaboratively contributing to the excellent performance. C2N and defect-containing N/C sheet-based SACs have also shown promising applications in selective hydrogenation, [25,45–48] as the defect or cavity is decorated with pyridinic N atom or unsaturated C atom, facilitating the dissociation of H2 molecule with low barrier and the adsorption of H with reasonable adsorption strength. In this study, we designed promising Co SACs models by modulating the electronic structure through heteroatom S doping and defect engineering strategies. The hydrogenation of nitrobenzene was adopted as a model reaction to test the hydrogenation performance of the obtained catalysts. By comparing 9 different catalyst models, the optimal candidate was identified to have an extremely low dissociation barrier for the H2 cleavage and H diffusion. The mechanism for the promoted activity of H2 dissociation and reasonable adsorption strength of the *H was then explored. Subsequently, the complete reaction pathways for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene were calculated and compared with other reported catalysts, with which the activity was analyzed. Based on the comprehensive analysis of the several factors affecting the reaction activity over nitrobenzene hydrogenation, design strategies for promising catalysts were proposed, providing insights into the design of efficient heterogeneous catalysts for other selective hydrogenation reactions. 2 Models and Theoretical details The catalyst models were constructed based on a nitrogen-doped graphene sheet, with several carbon atoms removed and replaced by single metal atoms, which were further decorated by nitrogen and sulfur atoms, forming Co SAC with various N/C/S coordination environments. The hexagonal 6 × 6 supercell from pristine graphene was used to construct the desired models, and the vacuum of 18 Å was set to avoid lateral interaction between two slabs. Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional [49] as implemented in Vienna ab initio simulation package [50–53] (VASP), and dipole correction was considered for all of the systems in this study. To accurately represent the spin state of the Co atom in this study, the DFT + U approach was applied to deal with the on-site Coulomb interactions in the localized d orbitals with U-J parameter of 3.3. The dispersion energy in the investigated systems was corrected by using Grimme’s scheme (DFT-D3). [54] The projected augmented wave (PAW) approach [55,56] was used to account for the interaction between the valence electrons and the atomic nucleus, and a kinetic cutoff energy of 450 eV was applied for all of the calculations. The Monkhorst-Pack scheme [57] with a k-point mesh of 2 × 2 × 1 was used to sample the Brillouin zone of the supercells in this study. The convergence criterion was met only when the energy difference was less than 1.0 × 10-5 eV, and the absolute force for each ion in the system was less than 0.02 eV/Å. The above parameters were found to give reliable results for the energies. The Bader charges for the atoms in the models were calculated by the method proposed by Tang and Henkelman. [58] The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [59] approach was adopted to search the transition states, where the force criterion for the calculations was set to 0.03 eV/Å3. The transition states were further confirmed by frequency calculations with only one imaginary vibrational frequency. The corrected Gibbs free energy (E Gibbs) for each state was calculated at the temperature of 308 K using equation (1): (1) E Gibbs = ZPE + U vib - T S vib where the ZPE, U vib, and S vib represent the zero point energy, vibrational internal energy and entropy, respectively. To evaluate the stability of each model, the binding energy (E bind) was calculated using equation (2): [43,60,61] (2) E bind = E Co/sub - E sub - E Co where the E Co/sub, E sub and E Co represent the energies of Co SAC, N/S doped graphene sheet, and cohesive energy of Co metal, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structures and stabilities of various cobalt SAC models To assess the impact of coordination number and defect site on H2 dissociation, nine distinct Co SAC models (Fig. 1 a-i and Figure S1) were constructed based on graphene sheet. In models a-e, the single Co site was coordinated to N and C atoms, and the models f-i were further doped with heteroatom S at the first or the second shell of the Co site. The primary source of stability for a specific SAC supported on graphene substrate is the ionic and covalent bonding between the metal atom and the support, as reported by Li and coworkers. [61] Therefore, the metal atom must form a strong bond with the graphene substrate to achieve high stability. In this study, the binding energy of Co atom in each model was calculated to evaluate its stability, [43,60] and a more negative value indicated higher stability for the model. More stability analyses were provided in Supporting Information and Figures S2-S3. The binding energies, bond lengths, and Bader charges are presented in Table 1 and Tables S1-S2. 3.1.1 Structures and stabilities of N-coordinated cobalt SACs The N-coordination numbers for models a (Co-N3) and b (Co-N4) were 3 and 4, respectively, achieved by removing 1 and 2 carbon atoms from a pristine graphene sheet (see Fig. 1a-1b). The Co-N4 catalyst exhibited higher stability with a binding energy of −4.10 eV compared to the value of −1.48 eV for the Co-N3 catalyst, as shown in Table 1. The binding energies were also reported using the Co bulk energy as the reference energy, resulting in slightly more positive values due to the energy difference between the Co cohesive energy and bulk energy (Table S3). The more negative binding energy supported the higher stability of Co SAC with the coordination of 4 N, which is in agreement with the successful syntheses of various transition metal (such as Fe, Ni, Co, etc.) based SACs with a coordination environment of 4 N. [2] Defective sites were constructed around the Co site, and the stabilities for the obtained SACs were analyzed. The model c (Co-N3-def, Fig. 1c) was built based on Co-N3 catalyst by removing C1 atom (see labeling in Fig. 1a), leading to a reconstruction of the local environment around the Co site and a binding energy of −1.15 eV. Alternatively, the model d (Co-N4-def, Fig. 1d) was formed by removing C2 (see labeling in Fig. 1b) from the Co-N4 model, resulting in two unsaturated (C, N) sites and a binding energy of −2.69 eV. Another defect-containing model e (Co-N5-def) that consists of 5 N atoms was built, where 2 N atoms (N2 and N5, see labels in Figure S1) were uncoordinated pyridinic N (base) sites, and the other 3 N atoms were coordinated to Co (acidic) site. The binding energy of the Co-N5-def model was calculated to be −2.98 eV, more negative than the values of models c and d. It is worthwhile noting that the Co atom in Co-N5-def was coordinated to three N sites with distances of 1.95, 1.88, and 1.94 Å (Table 1 and Table S1), respectively, and the two uncoordinated pyridinic N sites possessed d N-Co distances of 2.52 and 3.11 Å. Especially, the basic N2 and N5 sites with Bader charges of −2.44 and −2.48 |e| were sterically hindered away from the acidic Co site with a Bader charge of 1.31 |e|, mimicking the FLP. The Co-N bond length in defect-containing N-coordinated Co SACs greatly varies between 1.78 and 2.22 Å (Table S1), different from the equivalent Co-N bond lengths in defect-free Co-N3 and Co-N4 catalysts. This phenomenon can be attributed to the distortion effect due to the existence of the C/N defect, which also perturbed the electron population of Co and N atoms. The calculated Bader charges are listed in Table 1 and Table S2. Notably, the Bader charge of Co atom slightly varied from 1.31 to 1.58 |e| for the five N-coordinated cobalt SACs, with the Co atom in Co-N5-def catalyst possessing a relatively smaller value of 1.31 |e|. 3.1.2 Structures and stabilities of N, S-coordinated cobalt SACs To further fine-tune the electronic structures of the N, C-coordinated Co SACs, heteroatom sulfur (S) was introduced into the planar sheet, resulting in four new models f-i. Two catalyst models, Co-N3S and Co-N4S, without defect sites were initially analyzed. The Co-N3S (model f) features 3N1S coordination at the first shell, with the S atom elevated above the graphene sheet, which is identical to the model reported by Zhang and coworkers. [32] The Co-N4S (model g) has the Co atom coordinated to 4 N atoms, and the S doping is located at the second shell. Both models f and g exhibit negative binding energies of −2.41 and −3.77 eV, respectively (Table 1), indicating that they are thermodynamically stable and corroborating the successful synthesis of Co-N3S sample in experiment. Two defect-containing models were subsequently constructed for the N, S-containing SACs. The first defect-containing model h (Co-N3SN-def1) was obtained by removing 1 N atom from the Co-N4 model, and the two unsaturated C atoms were replaced by S and N1 atoms, respectively (see Figure S1 for labeling), with the S atom coordinated to Co site and the N atom becoming a pyridinic N. Surprisingly, the stability is satisfactory due to its negative formation energy of −1.53 eV, indicating that it possess a good stability with the presence of defect site and can be synthesized experimentally. Notably, the pyridinic N1 can act as a basic site, which is sterically hindered from the acidic Co site with d Co-N1 of 3.25 Å. The N1-Co pair mimics the well-known FLP sites, which have been reported to exhibit excellent performance in H2 dissociation. The Co-S bond distance is 2.26 Å, and the average bond length of the three Co-N bonds is 1.90 Å, both of which are in good agreement with the corresponding values of 2.28 and 1.92 Å obtained from extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) fitting. [32] In contrast, the bond length for Co-S and Co-N1 are 2.11 and 1.91 Å, respectively, in the defect-free Co-N3S model, and the value of 2.11 Å is much smaller than the experimental value. By exchanging the pyridinic N1 atom with one neighboring C atom in Co-N3SN-def1, it leads to another defect containing model, Co-N3SN-def2 (model l), with a binding energy of −2.02 eV. In summary, the introduction of S into the N-coordinated Co SACs results in calculated negative binding energies, indicating that the Co single atom can be stabilized in the graphene sheet, which is consistent with the successful synthesis of N, S-doped Co SACs in experiments. [32] The kinetic stability of Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst was also evaluated, which will be discussed in section 3.7.1. The S-doping affects the electronic properties, as evidenced by the decreased Bader charges for the Co atoms in the four N, S-coordinated Co SACs (Table 1). The smallest Bader charge of Co atom is 1.22 |e| in Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst, which is lower than the value of 1.31 |e| in Co-N5-def catalyst. The variation of electron population suggests that the introduction of S atom alters the local environment, which may also affect the adsorption of reactants. 3.2 H2 dissociation processes using cobalt SACs The dissociation of H2 molecule on SACs is a critical step in hydrogenation reactions and typically involves a higher energy barrier compared to that on the surfaces of metal nanoparticles and metal oxides, where the abundant M−M or M−O sites facilitate the cleavage of H2 molecules. Understanding the mechanism of H2 dissociation on SACs with various coordination environments surrounding single metal sites is crucial for designing SACs with high performance in hydrogenation reactions. The dissociation of the H2 molecule over the 9 catalyst models was modeled, and the reaction profiles are shown in Fig. 1j, along with the dissociation energies listed in Table 1. The structures during the dissociation processes are given in Fig. 2 . The results indicate that the dissociation barriers were significantly affected by the microenvironment of the Co site. 3.2.1 H2 cleavage using N-coordinated Co SACs without defect sites For the Co-N3 model, the H2 molecule is initially adsorbed at the Co site and subsequently dissociates into two *H species located at Co and C atoms (Fig. 2), respectively. This process is associated with a very high dissociation barrier of 1.88 eV and a reaction energy of 1.57 eV, indicating that the process is highly unfavorable both thermodynamically and kinetically. In the case of Co-N4 as the catalyst, the physisorbed H2 molecule at the Co site dissociates into *H(Co)+*H(N) by overcoming a high barrier of 1.74 eV and a high reaction energy of 1.80 eV. The transition state was confirmed by the presence of only one imaginary frequency corresponding to the vibration of the H-H bond. The slightly lower value of 1.74 eV for the barrier than the value of 1.80 eV for the reaction energy is due to the inclusion of corrected Gibbs energy. Clearly, the saturated N or C sites surrounding the Co site in models a and b are responsible for the high dissociation barrier. 3.2.2 H2 cleavage using N-coordinated Co SACs with defect sites The highly positive reaction energies for the Co-N3 and Co-N4 models suggest that the adsorption of *H is highly unfavorable at the saturated C/N sites with sp2 hybridization. To facilitate the heterolytic dissociation of H2, basic sites surrounding the Co center were created by constructing defect-containing Co SACs. The inclusion of defect sites significantly reduced the dissociation barriers. As shown in Fig. 1j, the H2 dissociation barrier utilizing Co-N3-def catalyst was dramatically reduced to 0.86 eV, with the two *H species located at Co and C sites, respectively (see Fig. 2). Furthermore, the same process using the Co-N4-def model was barrierless, with one dissociated *H species at the Co site and the other *H species at the unsaturated C site. The reaction energy was more negative with a value of −1.32 eV for Co-N4-def compared to the value of −0.15 eV for Co-N3-def model. In addition to C defective sites, the impact of N defect sites on H2 dissociation was also evaluated. The calculations show that the barrier for H2 cleavage using the Co-N5-def model was quite small with a value of only 0.26 eV, together with a slightly negative reaction energy of −0.16 eV (Fig. 1k). Fig. 2 clearly shows that the pyridine nitrogen (N2, Figure S1) in the Co-N5-def catalyst serves as an acceptor site for *H, which is sterically hindered from the Co site. The above results suggest that the dissociation barrier of the H2 molecule could be dramatically reduced for the Co SAC with defect site featuring pyridinic N or unsaturated C site. 3.2.3 H2 cleavage using defect-free N, S-coordinated Co SACs The incorporation of heteroatoms, such as S, O, and P into SACs has been reported to modify their electronic structures, consequently influencing their catalytic activities. [22,24,62] To explore how the S-doping affects the activity of H2 cleavage, the two catalyst models Co-N3S and Co-N4S were investigated. In the defect-free Co-N3S model, the preferred dissociation pathway involves H2 cleavage of H2 at the Co site and the C site adjacent to the S atom. The dissociation energy for this process was calculated to be 1.11 eV, with a reaction energy of 0.54 eV, indicating an endothermic reaction. Alternative H2 cleavage pathways at (Co, N) and (Co, S) sites were also considered (Figure S4), yielding energy barriers of 1.85 and 2.83 eV, respectively, along with reaction energies of 1.63 and 2.03 eV. Evidently, the reaction energy of the H2 cleavage correlates well with its dissociation energies, and (Co, C) sites are identified as the most effective sites for H2 cleavage. In contrast, the Co-N4S model requires a high energy barrier of 1.56 eV, with a reaction energy is 0.26 eV. The findings for the Co-N3S and Co-N4S models indicate that the S-doping at the first shell (Co-N3S) significantly reduces the dissociation barrier compared to that of Co-N4S model with S doping at the second shell. Notably, these barriers are lower than those of the two corresponding Co-N3 and Co-N4 models without S doping. Upon closer examination of the intermediate structures, it was observed that the Co-N4S undergoes structural changes during the H2 cleavage process. As depicted in Fig. 2, the N-S bond length increases from 1.67 Å in the initial state to 2.48 Å in the transition state and 2.68 Å in the final state, suggesting that the N-S bond breaks during the H2 cleavage. This implies that the calculated barrier does not solely represent the H2 cleavage process. The slightly lower barriers for H2 dissociation using the Co-N3S and Co-N4S catalysts indicate that S-doping has a minimal impact on dissociation barriers. This could be attributed to the suboptimal nature of the C or N site surrounding the Co sites for the binding of *H species. Therefore, the strategy involving the introduction of defect sites into the graphene sheet was also considered for N, S-coordinated Co SACs, with further details provided below. 3.2.4 H2 cleavage using defect-containing N, S-coordinated Co SACs Motivated by the influence of defects on N-coordinated Co SACs, the effect of defect sites based on the N, S-doped Co SACs was investigated in relation to their H2 cleavage activity. In the Co-N3SN-def2 model, structural relaxation occurs due to the removal of one C atom near the S atom, resulting in the formation of a new S-C1 bond and the retraction of the S atom back to the planar sheet. The formed S-C1 bond has a length of 2.09 Å, significantly longer than the average bond length of the other two S-C bonds, which is 1.79 Å. Consequently, H2 molecule dissociation occurs over the Co and N2 sites, with a high energy barrier of 1.54 eV, comparable to the 1.56 eV energy barrier observed in the Co-N4S model without defect sites. This outcome is logical, as the N2 site for adsorbing *H species is saturated with coordination. The exchange of C1 and N1 sites in the Co-N3SN-def2 model leads to the formation of Co-N3SN-def1 model, where the N1 site is a pyridinic N (Figure S4). As anticipated, the pyridinic N1 site and the Co site function as frustrated Lewis pair, facilitating the dissociation of the H2 molecule with a significantly lower energy barrier of only 0.37 eV. In conclusion, the reaction of a pyridinic N site at the defect site substantially reduces the high barrier of H2 cleavage to a relatively small value, which would significantly enhance the catalyst’s activity towards the heterolytic cleavage of H2 molecule. 3.2.5 Linear regression analysis of H2 dissociation energy and reaction energy Establishing a correlation between a straightforward descriptor and H2 dissociation across various Co SACs is of significant importance and utility in guiding the design of targeted catalysts. Typically, the Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) [63,64] relation is employed to correlate the dissociation energy with the adsorption strength of the active sites for intermediates. In the context of H2 dissociation on Co SACs surfaces, the reaction energy of H2 was plotted against the barriers of H2 cleavage for eight catalyst models, as depicted in Fig. 1k. The Co-N4S model was excluded from this analysis because its dissociation barrier does not only represent the cleavage of the H2 molecule, but also includes the breaking of the N-S bond. As shown in Fig. 1k, a good linear correlation exists between the barriers and the reaction energies, suggesting that the reaction energy of H2 can serve as a reliable descriptor for predicting the catalyst’s activity towards H2 cleavage. 3.3 Dissociation mechanism of H2 Unraveling the mechanism responsible for the enhanced activity in H2 cleavage is crucial for gaining a deeper insight into the properties of the desired catalyst and guiding the development of promising catalyst candidates. Consequently, the electronic properties of transition states for H2 cleavage using Co-N3S and Co-N3SN-def1 models were investigated by analyzing the charge density difference (CDD) and electron localization function (ELF). For the Co-N3S, as shown in Fig. 3 a, the distance between H1 and H2 atoms increases to 1.07 Å in the transition state compared to the 0.75 Å distance in the H2 molecule. Bader charge analysis reveal that the H1 and H2 atoms have charges of 0.12 and −0.20 |e|, respectively. The redistribution of the charge density is consistent with the CDD plot (Fig. 3b), which shows an accumulation of electrons around the H2 site and a depletion of electrons near the H1 site. In contrast, for the Co-N3SN-def1 model, as shown in Fig. 3e, the CDD plot indicates a similar trend of charge redistribution, with electron depletion occurring for the H1 atom near the N1 site and electron accumulation around the H2 atom near the Co site. Bader charge analysis reveals that the charge transfer in the transition state using the Co-N3SN-def1 model is stronger, with the H1 and H2 atoms have charges of 0.33 and −0.37 |e|, respectively (Fig. 3d). These findings suggest that there is a stronger electric field between the sterically hindered (Co) acidic site and (N1) basic site. Furthermore, the ELF analyses show that the electrons surrounding the H2 atom in the Co-N3S model are highly localized, and there is an increase of electron density between the H1 and C as shown in Fig. 3e, indicating a mainly covalent interaction between the H1 and C, as evidenced by the ELF value of approximately 0.5. In contrast, the interaction between the H2 and Co is Coulombic. For the Co-N3SN-def1 model, the interaction between the H1 and N1 is stronger, as indicated by an ELF value of approximately 0.7. Therefore, the stronger electric field between the H1 and N1, as well as the stronger covalent interaction, contribute to the heterolytic cleavage of H2 with a lower barrier using FLP containing Co-N3SN-def1 model. This phenomenon is similar to that observed in other FLP-containing catalysts, such as C2N and CeO2 based materials. [42,47] Thus, constructing FLP sites confined in the planar sheet of SACs is an effective strategy for boosting the cleavage of H2 molecules and potentially other H-source molecules as well. 3.4 H diffusion pathways In addition to the dissociation process of the H2 molecule, another crucial factor influencing the performance of hydrogenation reactions is the diffusion of dissociated *H species. Unlike metal nanoparticles, where both the dissociation of H2 and the diffusion of *H occur on the same surface of the metal, the isolated sites on the SAC catalysts actually impede the diffusion of *H. Previous investigations, both experimentally and theoretically, have seldom explored the detailed diffusion pathways, and the dissociated *H species was typically introduced into the active site (metal site or neighboring N site) during the hydrogenation reaction pathways. In this study, two primary diffusion paths were calculated and compared, focusing on the possible diffusion paths for *H species. One path involves the H diffusion on the surface of N-doped graphitic carbon (path A), while the other involves H diffusion with water solvent as the medium (path B). Taking the Co-N3SN-def1 as the catalyst, the path A for H diffusion commences from the dissociated state of *H1(Co)+*H2(N1) (IS1 in Fig. 4 ). This is followed by the diffusion paths of H1 to N2 site (IM1), C1 site (IM2), and C2 site (IM3). The three diffusion steps involve energy barriers of 0.90, 1.59, and 1.43 eV, respectively, and the reaction energies of 0.74, −0.03, and 0.49 eV, respectively. According to the energetic span model, [65] the rate determining states are the TS2 and the IS1, indicating an energetic span δE value of 2.33 eV. This suggests that the process is unlikely to occur under mild condition, indicating that the H diffusion via the surface C/N atoms on N-doped graphitic carbon sheet is challenging when the distances between neighboring metal sites are large or moderate. The H diffusion via the solvent of water was then investigated using an explicit water model with six H2O molecules. The six H2O molecules were optimized above the Co metal site anchored on the Co-N3SN-def model with dissociated *H1(Co)+*H2(N1), labeled as IS1a (or IS1b) in Fig. 4. Due to the steric hindrance between the two H atoms attached to the Co and N1 sites, the two H atoms are not confined in the planar sheet, and both of the Co-H1 and N1-H2 bonds point to water molecules in the explicit water model. A six-membered ring structure was observed in previous studies. [66] Considering the H2-N1 bond is stronger than the H2-Co bond, as revealed by the larger IpCOHP value in Figure S5, the diffusion of H2 into the solvent model was computed. The calculations show that the diffusion of H2 from the N1 site into the water solvent requires an energy barrier of 0.65 eV, indicating that the diffusion of dissociated *H species on the surface into the water solvent requires a moderate energy barrier, which could be overcome under mild condition. The calculations confirm that the H diffusion via water molecules from the solvents is feasible due to its moderate energy barrier. More importantly, the comparison of the diffusion paths indicates that the diffusion of H from the N site into the solvent is much easier than the direct diffusion path between two active sites on the planar sheet. Therefore, it is reasonable to hypothesize that the required H for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene comes from the neighboring active site on the planar sheet of the Co SAC. 3.5 Reaction pathways for selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene The hydrogenation of nitrobenzene has served as a model reaction to investigate the hydrogenation capability of the SAC catalysts in recent years. Theoretical studies have been conducted to elucidate the hydrogenation reactions by screening various metal atom-anchored SACs supported on graphitic carbon by Wang and coworkers, [30] where the second N-O breaking was proposed to be the rate-determining step. However, a complete reaction pathway for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene is still required, as the different reaction processes may compete with each other, leading to distinct reaction mechanisms. In this study, the Co-N3SN-def1 model was selected for investigation due to its high activity towards H2 cleavage and moderate barrier for H diffusion. The aim was to provide a comprehensive understanding of the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene over SACs. The hydrogenation of nitrobenzene commences with the adsorption of H2 on pristine Co-N3SN-def1 (IS1), as depicted in Fig. 5 . This process has an adsorption energy of −0.25 eV. Subsequently, the H2 molecule dissociates into *H(Co)+*H(N1), surmounting an energy barrier of 0.37 eV, resulting in the formation of IS2 intermediate. This process is slightly endothermic by 0.19 eV. The reactant PhNO2 is then physically adsorbed over the catalyst with an adsorption energy of −0.47 eV (IM1). The *H(Co) attacks the –NO2 group, forming *PhNOOH intermediate adsorbed at the Co site (IM2), with a low energy barrier of 0.26 eV. Following this, the *H(N1) transfers to the –NOOH group, leading to the cleavage of the first N-O bond and the formation of the *PhNO + H2O state (IM3), accompanied by a barrier of 0.44 eV. In the subsequent steps, the addition of *H was considered from the generated *H at neighboring sites via the diffusion path of solvent water molecules. After the removal of the formed H2O molecule and the addition of *H to the N1 site, the intermediate IM4 was obtained. The transfer of *H from the N1 site to the *PhNO results in the formation of *PhNOH intermediate with a very small barrier of 0.04 eV. An additional *H then adsorbs at the N1 site and transfers to the *PhNOH, leading to the breaking of the second N-O bond with a barrier of 0.39 eV and the formation of *PhN at the Co site (IM8). The reaction processes for the N-O breaking are all exothermic. The second N-O breaking requires a barrier of 0.39 eV, which is significantly lower than the values reported for various SACs in the literatures. [30,32] For instance, Wang and coworkers screened 12 late transition metal M1-N4/C SAC and found that the Ru1-N4/C SAC exhibits the best performance for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline. The rate-determining step in this reaction is the second N-O bond breaking, with an energy barrier of 0.99 eV, which is much higher that of the 0.39 eV barrier for the same reaction step in this study. Furthermore, the further hydrogenation of the *PhN into *PhNH and *PhNH2 are also exothermic and barrierless. According to the energetic span model, the δE value should be 0.53 eV, i.e., which is the energy difference between the transition state (TS67) for the breaking of the second N-O bond and the IM5 state. The diffusion barrier of 0.65 eV for the transfer of H from the surface to the solvent water is higher than the δE value of 0.53 eV for the processes of nitrobenzene hydrogenation. This suggests that the diffusion of H dominates the hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene, which is very different from previous studies where the second N-O breaking was usually regarded as the rate-determining step. The desorption of the product aniline is also an important process that affects the recovery of the catalyst. Therefore, the desorption energy was calculated for the adsorbed aniline at the Co site. For a comprehensive comparison, the desorption energies were calculated with and without an explicit water model. Without the solvent, the desorption energy was calculated to be 0.72 eV by removing the aniline away from the Co site. With the inclusion of the explicit water model (Figure S6), the desorption energy was slightly decreased to 0.65 eV, of which the value is coincidently the same as the diffusion barrier of *H with the explicit water model. As summarized in Table 2 , all of the hydrogenation processes possess barriers smaller than 0.44 eV, with relatively higher barriers for the breaking of the first N-O and the second N-O bonds. These two steps were then further calculated using explicit water models, and the barriers were slightly changed with values of 0.47 and 0.29 eV, respectively. In summary, the reaction energies for the hydrogenation processes are lower than the barrier for the *H diffusion and the desorption of aniline. These findings differ from previous investigations using SAC catalysts, where the rate-determining steps usually refer to the breaking of the N-O bond in the nitro group or the cleavage of the H2 molecule. [17,30,32,67] This phenomenon is also quite different from that observed in traditional metal nanoparticle-based catalysts, where the diffusion of H occurs easily on the metal surfaces under the experimental conditions, and the breaking of the second N-O bond usually dominates the activity.[68]. 3.6 Comparison of the activities using several different catalyst models Four catalyst models, namely Co-N4, Co-N5-def, Co-N3S, and Co-N3SN-def1, were chosen to investigate the barriers for the breaking of the second N-O bond, which were previously reported to have high barrier. [5,17,30,32,67] Since the *PhNOH intermediate is formed at the Co site, the subsequently hydrogenation process involving the addition of *H to a neighboring site next to the Co site was considered. For the Co-N4 model, as shown in Fig. 6 , the *H binds to a coordinated N site with an adsorption energy of 1.03 eV, indicating that this process is highly endothermic. In contrast, the addition of the *H to the N5 site of Co-N5-def is an exothermic process with an adsorption energy of −0.48 eV. This significant difference can be attributed to the trend of the activation energies for the two models, as discussed earlier. The attack of *H to the *PhNOH in the Co-N4 model is a low-barrier (0.09 eV) process, resulting in a δE value of 1.12 eV according to the energetic span model. In comparison, the δE value for the Co-N5-def model is 0.98 eV. For the S doped Co-N3S mode, the addition of *H to the N site is an endothermic process with an energy of 0.35 eV. A barrier of 0.73 eV is required for the subsequent hydrogenation process, leading to a δE value of 1.08 eV. In the case of the Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst, the pyridinic N site is capable of capturing the *H with a moderate adsorption energy of 0.15 eV. The transfer of the *H to the *PhNOH is accompanied by a low barrier of 0.39 eV, resulting in a δE value of 0.54 eV. Comparing the δE values of the four catalysts, it is evident that the Co-N3SN-def1 model has the lowest δE value of 0.54 eV, which is significantly lower than the values for Co-N5-def (0.98 eV), Co-N3S (1.08 eV), and Co-N4 (1.12 eV). The comparison clearly indicates that the Co-N3SN-def1 has the highest activity towards the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The moderate adsorption strength for the *H species captured by the pyridinic N in Co-N3SN-def1 plays a crucial role in lowering the barriers, and the pyridinic N acts as a reservoir for *H during the hydrogenation processes. 3.7 Discussions on the factors affecting the properties of the catalysts 3.7.1 Stability of Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst The stability of the proposed Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst was further examined by calculating the diffusion path for the single Co metal. The diffusion of the confined Co atom in the N3S1 cavity to the site above the pyridinic ring was simulated, as shown in Fig. 7 a. It was found that an extremely high barrier of 4.08 eV must be overcome for the diffusion of the confined Co atom, along with a positive reaction energy of 3.98 eV. These results further confirm that the single Co atom is trapped in the defect site under experimental conditions, indicating that the catalyst is stable both thermodynamically and kinetically. 3.7.2 Coordination environment of Co site EXAFS fitting is a widely used tool for identifying the chemical environment of the SACs. [32,46] It is essential to acknowledge that the fitting results are statistical in nature and only represent the local bonding information of the metal site. Acquiring information about the chemical environment of the second shell and beyond continues to be a challenge. Consequently, a meticulous examination of the local structure of SAC remains necessary, even after obtaining EXAFS fitting results. In this context, DFT calculation-aided catalyst models should be scrutinized with care, particularly for different combinations of the coordination atoms (such as C/N/S) and potential defects on the support. Notably, the bond length of 1.90 and 2.26 Å for the Co-N and Co-S (Co-N3SN-def1) bonds, respectively, are in good agreement with the corresponding EXAFS fitting values of 1.92 and 2.28 Å for samples with similar local environment. [32] In contrast, the bond length of 2.11 Å for the Co-S bond in the Co-N3S model that was proposed by Liu and coworkers [32] is much smaller than the EXAFS fitted value of 2.28 Å. Given the good thermodynamic stability of Co-N3SN-def1 and the presence of the same N3S coordination in Co-N3S, it is plausible to speculate that the Co-N3SN-def1 site may coexist with the Co-N3S site in the sample synthesized experimentally. 3.7.3 The effect of sulfur doping To elucidate the effect of sulfur doping, the two models Co-N3SN-def1 and Co-N5-def were compared. The calculated Bader charge (see Table S2) for the sulfur atom is positive with a value of 0.22 |e|, while the nitrogen site at the similar site in the Co-N5-def model is −2.44 |e|. This difference results in a redistribution of charge around the Co metal site, leading to a decrease in the Bader charge of the Co atom from 1.31 |e| to 1.22 |e|. This alternation weakens the adsorption strength of *H at the pyridinic N site to some extent, as evidenced by the more positive reaction energy of 0.20 eV for the H2 cleavage using the Co-N3SN-def1 catalyst compared to the value of −0.16 eV using the Co-N5-def catalyst. This change positively contributes to the hydrogenation process, as revealed by the lower barrier using Co-N3SN-def1 for the breaking of the second N-O bond, as shown in Fig. 6e. In conclusion, sulfur doping further enhances the activity of the nitrobenzene hydrogenation, thereby demonstrating that sulfur doping is an effective strategy. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, density functional theory calculations have successfully elucidated the structure–property relationship between the hydrogenation activity and the structures of the N, S-decorated Co SACs. Among the designed catalyst candidates, the Co-N3SN-def1 model with pyridinic N at the defect site exhibits optimal activity towards the heterolytic cleavage of the H2 molecule, H diffusion, and subsequent hydrogenation steps during the reduction of nitrobenzene. Notably, the barriers for the H2 cleavage and breaking of N-O bonds are very small, with values smaller than 0.44 eV, making the diffusion of the *H via the explicit water model and the desorption processes as the rate-determining steps with barrier/desorption energy of only 0.65 eV. Electronic structure analyses reveal an enhanced electric field between the pyridinic N and the Co atoms in the FLP sites of the Co-N3SN-def1 model, which significantly contributes to the cleavage of the H2 molecule. Furthermore, the pyridinic N site acts as a reservoir for the binding of *H with reasonable adsorption strength, facilitating the hydrogenation steps. The doping of S into the catalyst is also crucial as it modulates the adsorption strength of *H at the N site, benefiting the reaction processes. The mechanism unraveled in this study provides valuable insights into the design of SACs for targeted hydrogenation reactions. coredata.dc:description: The limitation of isolated metal active sites in single atom catalysts (SAC) hinder their application in hydrogenation reactions, necessitating the creation of additional active site beyond the metal site. This study introduces pyridinic N and S atoms into the N/C sheet, optimally adjusting the local environment of the Co site. This adjustment synergistically enhances H2 activation, H diffusion, and promotes the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline. The sterically hindered Co acidic site and N basic site, known as frustrated Lewis pairs, in defect-containing Co-N3SN-def1 model cooperatively facilitate the highly efficient cleavage of the H2 molecule with a barrier of only 0.37 eV. The findings suggest that the pyridinic N site in the Co-N3SN-def1 model acts as a reservoir for *H, significantly contributing to the enhanced activity for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The mechanism unveiled in this study offers valuable insights for designing efficient heterogeneous catalysts for target hydrogenation reactions.

coredata.dc:title: Theoretical evidence on pyridinic nitrogen in N, S-coordinated Co single atom catalyst as dominant active site promoting H2 cleavage, H diffusion, and hydrogenation activity
